content.content: I feel there might be some  people that are missing where and when Emergency Shutdown (ES) originated. The Emergency Shutdown (correct me if I am mistaken) is a leftover from the TheDAO disaster in 2016. Lesson learned: there must be a way to shut down a system that has serious vulnerabilities or is outright malfunctioning. On paper Emergency Shutdown worked, but the world of crypto has moved on since then. In 2016 the various blockchains and teams were more or less operating independently with the major problem being faulty code. In 2020 coding errors are fewer and crypto is rapidly integrating across both projects and blockchains - and in the case of Maker even starting to bridge into real world assets. The net effect of this is that the negative consequences of an Emergency Shutdown have increased hugely and is something that should be avoided at nearly all cost. It is generally a much better option to use DarkSpells or Emergency Voting for handling serious situations. Emergency Shutdown, while still possible, is gradually slipping lower and lower down on the menu of options.

content.content: The FAQ can be found here: https://community-development.makerdao.com/makerdao-mcd-faqs/faqs/emergency-shutdown There are two main ways of activating ES. Either by executive vote, or using the Emergency Shutdown Module. The ESM allows 50,000 total MKR to trigger ES, but that MKR is locked in the ESM and can only be restored as part of a redeployment (and only if the rest of the MKR Holders think that it was a good idea to shut down.) Realistically this may lead to a fork of the protocol.

content.content: The product is not breaking and there is no security threat, it is still dampening the volatility of it’s underlying collateral significantly.  We just haven’t been able to successfully meet the demand for Dai to bring the peg to perfect equilibrium. One idea is to  create a standard deviation for ‘the peg’ that’s acceptable, which changes throughout the roadmap of Dai, with a narrower band of acceptable deviation from the $1 peg as the product matures and time goes on.  If we stray from the defined band for a certain period of time, we could consider more drastic action.  With a larger supply and more diverse collateral, we will naturally convene at $1 over time; IMO we should be forgiving in the short term. I know this seems dramatic or dismissive to some, but the market doesn’t seem to care that the peg is off by a bit.  In fact, adoption, usage, demand, and liquidity for Dai has been the highest it’s ever been despite the peg being off.  The foundation has mentioned the peg being off hampering credibility/adoption of Dai, but the market is telling us otherwise.  We have some serious network effects and adoption like we’ve never seen before in the history of Dai.  I think when we get into the 10-20% territory consistently or start behaving like AMPL’s price we will start to lose complete credibility–and it will be obvious that we need to shut down. Dai is nascent and growing experiment and compared to the volatility of it’s underlying collateral, is performing exceptionally well.  We must continue to grow aggressively, not shut down.

content.content: If DAI is off the peg too much (0.5%) and too often then it’s not a stablecoin. If it is not stable then you cannot trust it. It’s like a building that swings a bit when the wind blows but usually not more than 4%. The point is that both DAI (if it cannot be controlled) and the building could collapse without further warning.

Dai is very much a stablecoin even if it is a bit off the peg. As we speak Dai is in red hot demand as defi fuel even if the peg is off by nearly 5%. So clearly it is trusted, clearly it is useful and clearly regarded as sufficiently stable for defi purposes. The problem comes with adoption outside of crypto. Once you deviate from the peg by more than 1% you will start having problems financing fiat use cases such as accounts payable financing.
